This recipe is for Spanish patties, or <em>Tinas</em>; a great favourite at EL PIANO, in York and in Andalucia

Cafe No. 8

What to do as a student on a Saturday night? 'Salvation, Tokyo and Ziggy's' are full of the over thirties/lonely hearts and apparently no one (particularly YUSU) likes Gallery anymore

Pub

Sometimes you just know you're going to have a good night. Walking towards <strong>The Maltings</strong> last Thursday I bumped into none other than Brendan Sheerin, of Coach Trip fame. To say I was star struck would be an understatement

The Churchill Hotel

There is simply no argument strong enough to dispute the well established fact that student eating habits fall into one of two categories; student cooking or takeaways. Take your pick (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Sam Newsome)

Wine

After the undeniably delightful debauchery of Freshers' Week, the Week Three grim can hit even the hardiest of freshers

Pub

Let's start with the bad news. The House of Trembling Madness, on Stonegate, is not somewhere to save the pennies. There's no way to get round the fact that it's PS3.50 a pint across the board here, but telling you that now means the only way is up from here (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Sam Newsome)

The Sanctuary

The Sanctuary was recommended to me as somewhere pleasant, yet not too pricey, when I had a friend to stay and needed somewhere reasonably nice

Wine

You've finished exams and essays and have the prospect of a long and unproductive summer ahead

Pub

"Students weren't welcome here before," said the cheerful landlady as she pulled my pint of Timothy Taylor's

Asia Gourmet

Looks can be deceiving and I sincerely hoped so when I stood outside Asia Gourmet on a warm spring evening

Wine

It's midway through spring and, in true British style, we behave as if it's already the height of summer. The abundance of barbeques, Pimms-fuelled parties and long lunches is testimony to our eagerness to don the sunglasses and flip-flops at even the slightest hint of summer-esque weather

Pub

Despite it being the first warm day of the year, I shouldered the frankly enormous responsibility of a Nouse pub columnist and decided to get myself to a boozer

Thirteen Thirty One

Certainly, tread very carefully when entering an establishment that peddles food by day and drunkenness by night

The Courtyard

Inspired by the elections last term, I decided it was time to take a stand. I launched my own one-man guerrilla campaign on the YUSU suggestion box. I was going to get pancakes on the menu if it killed me

Pub

First things first, York's Hole in the Wall has nothing to do with that ghastly Saturday night TV show, and the Petergate pub doesn't need silver lycra to draw a crowd

Pub

Squished between the bookshops and restaurants of Fossgate, the varnished red bricks of the Blue Bell look as if they belong in a Victorian underground station - certainly not a pokey little street in North Yorkshire

Wine

It is at this stage of the term that we realise quite how poor we really are. Personally, I've a fondness for ignoring such dull notions as debt, budgeting and thrift

Khao San

Khao San Rd, deemed the 'new Thai restaurant on the block', immediately grabbed my attention. I couldn't wait to go in and take a look around, especially as Thai is one of my favourite cuisines

Melton's

When I say I have eaten at Melton's, everyone seems to automatically assume I am talking about its sister restaurant Melton's Too in Walmgate (Thumbnail credit Photo: Jason Lozier)

Wine

I dislike Lent. 960 hours of self-imposed, self-righteous misery. To inflict cravings upon yourself for 40 days only to return to your bad habits immediately afterward seems a little daft

Pub

I've had previous experimence with this establishment (Thumbnail credit Photo: Jason Lozier)

The Blue Bicycle

Although The Blue Bicycle is a firm spot on the list of fine dining resturants in York, I had heard mixed reviews (Thumbnail credit Photo: Sam Newsome)

Wine

Whilst I admit to being hopeless at embracing the more thrifty aspects of the student lifestyle, at this most bleak time of year I firmly believe that extravagance is not only justified, but should be encouraged

Pub

The massive problem of balancing tradition and modernity has ensured that pubs have been receding as fast as Jude Law's hairline in recent years. Nestled in amongst the corporate coffee giants though, the Hansom Cab has seemingly got the balance just right (Thumbnail credit Photo: Same Newsome)

The Living Room

According to the Living Room website, the restaurant is 'chic, upbeat and welcoming'. They were entirely right

The Rook & Gaskill Inn

Situated on Lawrence Street, The Rook & Gaskill is a drinking pub

Wine

As the Australian wine connoisseur Len Evans so wisely said, "you can only have so many bottles in your life. Never drink a bad one"

Wine

Chekhov once said that "people don't notice whether it's winter or summer when they're happy".

Toto's Restaurant & Pizzeria

In what appeared to be a bid to find the cheapest grease-pool presented on a tomato-mozzarella-pepperoni plate, my flatmates have almost every night, without fail, produced a brand new soggy cardboard box containing our 'dinner'.
